importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage took place in late 2022, marking the timeframe during which the deep-sea explorations occurred and new species were first discovered.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2022 to 2025 encompasses the initial discovery and ongoing scientific evaluation of the new species, with estimates suggesting around 600 more species remain to be described.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent crab about the size of an almond and a tiny glowing lantern shark have been discovered in the deep sea off Western Australia.
The West Australian Lantern Shark, up to 40cm long, has large eyes and a glowing belly and was found over 600 meters below sea level.
A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in length, uses hairs to catch food instead of claws, feeding on plankton via filter feeding.
The discoveries were made during a research voyage by CSIRO in the Gascoyne Marine Park, approximately 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
Australia is a global biodiversity hotspot with over a million species, many of which remain unexplored due to the vast depth and inaccessibility of its waters.
The voyage has led to the identification of about 20 new species, including the Carnavon Flapjack Octopus.
It is estimated that around 600 more species remain to be described and named, due to the time required for scientific validation and classification.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in the Southern Hemisphere, known for its rich biodiversity and extensive marine ecosystems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia is one of the world’s biggest biodiversity hotspots, hosting more than a million species, many of which are unique and not found elsewhere on Earth, making it a key location for deep-sea species discovery.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency, responsible for scientific research and innovation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO conducted the deep-sea research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park, directly leading to the discovery of new species such as the West Australian Lantern Shark and the porcelain crab.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deep-sea exploration took place within this marine park, where unexplored depths contributed to the discovery of new species, highlighting the area's ecological significance.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered species of lantern shark found in deep ocean waters, growing up to 40cm and exhibiting bioluminescence.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is a key example of deep-sea adaptation, with bioluminescence on the belly and flanks, demonstrating evolutionary responses to deep ocean conditions.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain Crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of crab known for its filter-feeding behavior using long hairs on its mouthparts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The new porcelain crab species discovered in a depth of 122 meters uses hairs to catch plankton, differing from typical crab feeding methods and illustrating unique evolutionary adaptations.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered octopus species about 4cm in size, described as rusty red.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It adds to the growing list of species identified from the 2022 expedition, showing the diversity of marine life in Australia’s deep waters.

namedEntities.name: Western Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in Australia known for its extensive coastlines and deep-sea marine environments.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The discoveries occurred off the coast of Western Australia, emphasizing the region’s importance in deep-sea biodiversity and unexplored ecological zones.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist involved in the research, specializing in deep-sea species.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert insight into the bioluminescent properties of lantern sharks, contributing to the understanding of their biological adaptations.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum, involved in the research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He explained the filter-feeding behavior of the porcelain crab, offering key scientific context for understanding the species' unique feeding mechanism.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO discovered two new species during a deep-sea expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park off Western Australia. These include the West Australian Lantern Shark, a glowing shark found over 600 meters below sea level with large eyes and bioluminescent features, and a new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm long, which feeds on plankton using long hairs instead of claws. The research highlights Australia’s vast biodiversity and the continued discovery of unknown marine life in unexplored deep-sea zones. While 20 species have been identified so far, scientists estimate around 600 more remain to be described and validated due to the time required for scientific analysis.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
